titleInfo.title: Context Matters
titleInfo.subTitle: Advancing Equity in Public Management, Policy Design, and Policy Implementation

name.namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.abstract: This dissertation focuses on state-level interventions that deliver Federal policies to local recipients and investigates how policy design and implementation influence social equity outcomes, one of the core values of public administration. Notably, three essays in this dissertation provide original theoretical and practical contributions by focusing on the contexts that shape the direction and effectiveness of policy design and implementation. The first essay explores the impact of affirmative action bans at the state level on female representation in law enforcement. This study finds that affirmative action bans disproportionately reduce female representation, even though the legislation asserts neutrality. The original theoretical framework developed in this study expands the scope of representative bureaucracy by highlighting that policy interventions and historical passive representation can shape current and future passive representation. The second essay examines contracting out and the social equity outcomes at the program partner and service recipient levels. Utilizing the publicness framework, the findings suggest that public agencies and quasi-public authorities yield better social equity outcomes than private entities when delivering federal grant programs to small businesses. This study bridges the scholarship on contracting out with the publicness framework, emphasizing the importance of publicness in achieving equitable resource distribution. The third essay focuses on the role of external assistance organizations in mitigating administrative burdens in the Federal economic development and technology transfer program. The study shows that the presence of external assistance organizations at the state level enhances client success, particularly in states with less favorable policy environments characterized by lower job creation rates. This study fills gaps in the scholarship on administrative burdens by highlighting the role of external assistance organizations in economic development. Overall, this dissertation demonstrates that variations in policy design and implementation significantly shape social equity outcomes across different contexts. Each of the three essays offers theoretical contributions by expanding the scope of existing theories, connecting different literatures, and filling gaps in scholarship. Furthermore, the findings suggest practical implications for policymakers, emphasizing the need for nuanced policy design and implementation to promote social equity in public administration.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Askew School of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Daniel L. Fay, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael McFarland, University Representative; Frances Stokes Berry, Committee Member; Danielle Atkins, Committee Member.
